0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-trump-lawsuit-hearing-idUSKBN1351CB	Judge tells Trump University litigants they would be wise to settle	"
By Dan Levine and Karen Freifeld
| SAN DIEGO

SAN DIEGO The U.S. judge overseeing a lawsuit against President-elect Donald Trump and his Trump University told both sides they would be wise to settle the case ""given all else that's involved.""Lawyers for the president-elect are squaring off against students who claim they were they were lured by false promises to pay up to $35
column2: 000 to learn Trump's real estate investing ""secrets"" from his ""hand-picked"" instructors. Earlier on Thursday
column3: U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel tentatively rejected a bid by Trump to keep a wide range of statements from the presidential campaign out of the fraud trial.Trump owned 92 percent of Trump University and had control over all major decisions
column4: the students' court papers say. The president-elect denies the allegations and has argued that he relied on others to manage the business. Trial is scheduled to begin Nov. 28
column5: and Curiel told lawyers he was not inclined to delay the six-year-old case further. Trump lawyer Daniel Petrocelli said he would ask to put the trial on hold until early next year
column6: in light of the many tasks the magnate has before his inauguration.Curiel said he would allow both sides to file briefs on whether to delay the case. He also indicated they should consider making a deal.

column1: It would be wise for the plaintiffs
column2: for the defendants
column3: to look closely at trying to resolve this case given all else that's involved
column4: Curiel said.Petrocelli told reporters after the hearing that Trump might have to be a ""little more flexible"" about settling the case now that he is president-elect
column5: although the lawyer wasn't sure his client would was willing.Curiel said that he would allow Trump to testify via video given his presidential obligations.

column1: In the tentative ruling Curiel
column2: based in San Diego
column3: said Trump's lawyers can renew objections to specific campaign statements and evidence during trial. Trump's attorneys had argued that jurors should not hear about statements Trump made during the campaign
column4: including about Curiel himself.Trump attacked the judge as biased against him. He claimed Curiel
column5: who was born in Indiana but is of Mexican descent
column6: could not be impartial because of Trump's pledge to build a wall between the United States and Mexico. Trump's lawyers argued that Curiel should bar from the trial accusations about Trump's personal conduct including alleged sexual misconduct
column8: along with speeches and tweets. They argued the information is irrelevant to the jury and prejudicial to the case.

column1: In court papers
column2: lawyers for the students claimed that Trump's statements would help jurors as they weigh the Republican's credibility.""Defendants have not identified specific evidence that they wish to exclude
column3: Curiel wrote on Thursday. ""Accordingly
column4: the court declines to issue a blanket ruling at this time.""The judge also barred Trump lawyers from telling jurors that the university had a 98 percent approval rate on student evaluations. That rating is irrelevant as to whether Trump University misrepresented itself
column5: Curiel wrote.Curiel is presiding over two cases against Trump and the university. A separate lawsuit by New York's attorney general is pending. (Reporting by Dan Levine in San Diego and Karen Freifeld in New York; Editing by Peter Henderson and Cynthia Osterman)"	['Trump']	[]

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-immigration-idUSKBN135284	Glitch briefly removes 'Muslim ban' proposal from Trump website	"
By Emily Flitter
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Some of the most controversial proposals Donald Trump made while running for U.S. president disappeared from his campaign website on Thursday
column2: but a spokesman said what some observers took as a softening of Trump's policies was due to a technical glitch.The link to Trump's Dec. 7 proposal titled: ""Donald J. Trump statement on Preventing Muslim Immigration
column3: in which he called for ""a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States"" vanished temporarily from the website but later reappeared.So too did a list of Trump's potential Supreme Court justice picks as president and certain details of his economic
column4: defense and regulatory reform plans.""The website was temporarily redirecting all specific press release pages to the home page
column5: Trump spokesman Steven Cheung said in an email. Links to Trump's policy proposals
column7: were working again by 3:30 p.m. EST (2030 GMT).The links
column8: which had redirected readers to a campaign fundraising page
column9: appeared to have been removed around Election Day on Tuesday
column10: when Trump won a historic upset against Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column11: according to a website that records historic snapshots of web pages.

column1: In an appearance on CNBC on Thursday
column2: Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal praised Trump for removing the Muslim ban proposal from his website and also said Trump had deleted statements offensive to Muslims from his Twitter account.The prince could not be reached for comment after the links were restored.Several tweets attacking Muslims that Trump sent while campaigning for president remained in his feed on Thursday
column3: including a March 22 tweet in which Trump wrote:

column1: Incompetent Hillary
column2: despite the horrible attack in Brussels today
column3: wants borders to be weak and open-and let the Muslims flow in. No way!""After initially praising the removal of the Muslim ban proposal at a news conference with other civil rights leaders on Thursday
column4: Samer Khalaf
column5: president of the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee
column6: said in a follow-up interview the group was hoping to see better behavior from Trump.""False hope just came over us
column8: but ""we didn't really think it was monumental that they took down the language.""

column1: Khalaf said Trump's policies were more important than any statements. ""He's elected
column2: he said some horrible things
column3: now we have to see what his policies are. If they're good policies we're going to commend him for it. If they're horrible policies we're going to challenge him on it.""Despite the temporary glitch
column4: most of Trump's core policy positions had remained on his website
column5: including his central immigration promise to build an ""impenetrable physical wall"" on the border with Mexico and make Mexico pay for its construction.It was not the first time the Trump campaign blamed technical difficulties for changes to its website. The campaign this year also replaced the part of the site describing Trump's healthcare policy with a different version. When contacted about it by Reuters in September
column6: the campaign put the original page back up. (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson and Julia Harte in Washington
column7: Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Tom Brown)"	['Trump']	['healthcare']

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-illinois-crime-idUSKBN1352K5	Ex-congressman indicted on 24 counts in spending scandal	"

CHICAGO A former U.S. representative whose lavish office in Washington raised questions about use of taxpayer dollars was indicted on Thursday on charges of defrauding the federal government and campaign committees and attempting to cover it up
column2: according to court documents. Aaron Schock
column3: a 35-year-old former Republican congressman from Illinois
column4: was indicted by the U.S. Department of Justice on 24 counts
column6: theft of government funds and filing false federal income tax returns. Schock maintained his innocence on Thursday before the indictment was announced. ""Neither I nor anyone else intentionally did anything wrong
column7: he said in a statement. ""As I have said before
column8: we might have made errors among a few of the thousands and thousands of financial transactions we conducted
column9: but they were honest mistakes - no one intended to break any law."" Schock's position in public office did not put him above the law
column10: the Department of Justice said. ""These charges allege that Mr. Schock deliberately and repeatedly violated federal law
column11: to his personal and financial advantage
column13: U.S. attorney for the Central District of Illinois
column14: said in a statement on Thursday.

column1: Mr. Schock held public office at the time of the alleged offenses
column2: but public office does not exempt him or anyone else from accountability for alleged intentional misuse of public funds and campaign funds.""Schock
column3: elected to the
column4: U.S. House of Representatives in 2008 at the age of 27
column5: gained a following for posting flashy photos on social media of himself traveling around the world. But he was hounded with questions after The Washington Post reported last year about lavish decorations in his Capitol Hill office based on the PBS period melodrama ""Downton Abbey.""

column1: Although staff told the Post that the interior design work had been done for free
column2: the story prompted more investigations into Schock's spending habits
column3: with several media outlets reporting he failed to disclose some expenditures and had to repay others after improperly using taxpayer funds.On Thursday
column4: Schock said before the indictment that his faith in the Justice Department had been eroded.

column1: This indictment will look bad
column2: but underneath it is just made-up allegations of criminal activity arising from unintentional administrative errors
column3: George Terwilliger III
column4: Schock's attorney
column5: said in a statement prior to the indictment.  A summons will be issued to Schock by the U.S. Clerk of the  Court for an arraignment date in Springfield
column6: Illinois. (Reporting by Timothy Mclaughlin in Chicago and Julia Harte in Washington; Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Hill']	[]

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obamacare-white-house-idUSKBN1352G3	White House says Obamacare enrollment a priority	"

WASHINGTON Getting more Americans to enroll for health insurance under President Barack Obama's healthcare law known as Obamacare is a top priority of his administration until President-elect Donald Trump takes office on Jan. 20
column2: the White House said on Thursday.""We would be focused on ... maximizing the opportunity that currently is available for millions of Americans to go to healthcare.gov during the open enrollment period and sign up for healthcare
column3: White House spokesman Josh Earnest told a news briefing.Sylvia Burwell
column4: the secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
column5: tweeted on Thursday that Nov. 9 was HealthCare.gov's best day with 100
column6: 000 sign-ups since it began selling the 2017 Obamacare plans on Nov. 1. The government's goal is for more than 13.8 million sign-ups initially.Trump has said that he plans to repeal Obamacare
column7: formally known as the Affordable Care Act. Insurers have said that 2017 Obamacare plans will remain in place and that any changes would affect 2018 plans.

column1: Earnest said that people should not worry about what could happen to the healthcare exchanges under the Trump administration.""These are benefits that are available to them today. We certainly would encourage people to sign up and capitalize on the good opportunity that's there
column2: he said.

column1: Obama met with Trump on Thursday for the first time in a one-on-one
column2: 90-minute meeting in the White House Oval Office.    Trump also released a review of his goals to overhaul healthcare on his website
column3: reiterating that he would repeal the Affordable Care Act.

column1: Trump's pledge to repeal Obamacare may not be easy. He does not have the votes in Congress for an outright repeal and will have to cut away at its financing first
column2: health policy experts say. (Reporting by Susan Heavey and Caroline Humer in New York; Writing by Mohammad Zargham; Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Trump'
column3: 'Obama']	['healthcare']

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-mood-idUSKBN134353	'Rage against the machine': U.S. voters reject a 'rigged' system	"
By Andy Sullivan and Michelle Conlin

(This November 9th story has been refiled to clarify that Keyes comment in 3rd paragraph from end was said in jest)By Andy Sullivan and Michelle ConlinWASHINGTON In a bitterly divisive presidential election
column2: at least one thing united U.S. voters: a feeling that the country's economic and political systems were tilted against them.A Reuters/Ipsos Election Day poll of 45
column3: 000 voters found an electorate burning with resentment against Wall Street
column4: politicians and the news media
column5: increasingly alienated from a country that is changing in ways it doesn't like.This sense of alienation transcended partisan boundaries
column6: uniting supporters of Republican victor Donald Trump and his  Democratic rival
column7: Hillary Clinton.""This is rage against the machine
column9: a former supporter of Democratic President Barack Obama
column10: as fellow Trump supporters celebrated the real-estate mogul's victory early Wednesday by pouring champagne on each other at his $200 million luxury hotel near the White House.Some 75 percent of poll respondents
column12: agreed that the country needs a ""strong leader"" to take the country back from the rich and powerful. Seven out of ten agreed that the economy is ""rigged"" to benefit wealthy insiders. Most backed the notion that their leaders were out of touch: 77 percent of Trump supporters and 56 percent of Clinton supporters agreed that traditional politicians didn't care about people like them.(Graphic of Reuters/Ipsos poll: tmsnrt.rs/2ffJJ9A) This sense of disconnection ran deepest among Trump supporters. Some 73 percent agreed with the idea that ""more and more
column13: I don't identify with what America has become
column14: while 61 percent said they felt like strangers in their own country. Most Clinton supporters said they didn't share those sentiments.Nine out of ten Trump supporters said mainstream media is more interested in making money than telling the truth. Trump
column15: who travels in his own 757 jet
column16: might seem like an unlikely candidate to benefit from this anti-elite sentiment.

column1: But by 8 p.m. Eastern time
column2: lines had formed at the velvet ropes by 8 p.m. Eastern time outside Trump's new hotel in between the White House and the U.S. Capitol
column3: where a steak costs $60 and wine is sold by the spoonful. ""These are shadow voters
column4: voters who have never voted before
column7: who was watching the results with a throng of friends
column8: all of them wearing suits and Trump campaign trucker hats.Despite his gilded lifestyle
column9: Trump capitalized on working-class fears of a rapidly changing country. Styling himself as a ""blue-collar billionaire
column10: he promised to bring back manufacturing jobs back to forgotten factory towns and sharply curtail immigration. He drew overwhelming support from white working-class voters in Rust Belt states like Ohio and Pennsylvania
column11: winning enough states to capture the White House even as he lost the popular vote.Trump's scathing characterization of Clinton as a corrupt career politician also resonated in an year when many voters said they were primarily casting a vote against one of the candidates.

column1: VOTING AGAINST CANDIDATE
Some 46 percent of Trump supporters said they backed him because they didn't want Clinton to win
column2: while 40 percent of Clinton supporters said they were motivated primarily to stop Trump from reaching the White House. Those who made up their minds in the last week of the campaign were more likely to cite opposition to one of the candidates as their main reason for voting.Politicians like Clinton are ""taking away from what we were as a country and saying we should change because of the people coming in
column3: the immigrants and refugees
column4: said John Scherer
column5: a 57-year-old former maintenance worker in Portsmouth
column6: Ohio.Scherer's sentiments were widely shared by Trump supporters
column7: as 72 percent agreed with the idea that immigrants threaten traditional American beliefs and customs. Three-quarters of Clinton backers

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos Election Day poll was conducted online in English in all 50 states
column2: including more than 45
column3: 000 people who already voted in the presidential election.Voter dissatisfaction isn't exactly new. Surveys have consistently found since 2002 that most people believe the country is on the wrong track
column4: a period that encompasses a Republican and Democratic president
column6: a deep recession and a slow recovery.Trump supporters were more likely to share this frustration. Some 70 percent who backed the Republican real-estate mogul said they felt the country was on the wrong track
column7: while only 23 percent of Clinton supporters agreed
column8: according to the Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll.Those figures could quickly turn on their head as the reality of a Trump presidency sinks in. Across the country
column9: Clinton supporters used unusually harsh language when describing the election result. In Washington
column11: non-profit manager Trisha Postyuk said she saw her vote for Clinton as ""a triumph over evil."" In St. Petersburg
column15: said racist and sexist attitudes are going to take many years to overcome.""Misogyny will continue to bubble through the country but I can only hope that the old people will die
column17: a couple from Atlanta looked at a text message from a friend who had bet them $100 that Trump would lose. ""Please don't ever text me again
column18: the message said.     (Additional reporting by Emily Flitter in Ohio
column19: Ian Simpson in Washington and Letitia Stein in Florida; editing by Stuart Grudgings.)"	['Sullivan'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-putin-trump-idUSKBN1352J9	Trump's foreign policy approach almost same as that of Putin: Kremlin	"
By Andrew Osborn
| MOSCOW
MOSCOW The Kremlin said on Thursday U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's foreign policy approach was ""phenomenally close"" to that of President Vladimir Putin
column2: giving Russia hope that tattered U.S.-Russia relations could gradually be improved.Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov
column3: speaking in New York
column4: said he saw incredible similarities between the two men's foreign policy ideas
column5: and this meant there was a solid basis to start a meaningful dialogue between Moscow and Washington.         Peskov
column6: in the United States for a chess tournament
column7: said he was struck by how similar parts of Trump's victory speech were to a speech Putin gave in southern Russia last month. Both men said they would put their own country's national interests first
column8: but that they would be ready to develop ties with other nations
column9: depending on how ready other countries were to deepen relations themselves.

column1: They (Putin and Trump) set out the same main foreign policy principles and that is incredible
column2: Peskov said in comments broadcast by Russian state TV's Channel One on Thursday evening.""It is phenomenal how close they are to one another when it comes to their conceptual approach to foreign policy. And that is probably a good basis for our moderate optimism that they will at least be able to start a dialogue to start to clear out the Augean stables in our bilateral relations.""

column1: With Moscow and Washington now at odds over Syria
column2: Ukraine and NATO
column3: Peskov cautioned that it would take a long time before relations could return to a high level
column4: however
column5: because of how far they had been allowed to deteriorate.""An atmosphere of mutual trust takes years to achieve
column6: he said. ""It's not possible to just declare that there is an atmosphere of mutual trust
column7: especially after such serious damage was done in the last few years to our relations.""

column1: Peskov told the TASS news agency separately that Putin was ready to be flexible when it came to mending ties which he wanted to improve
column2: but that there was a limit to his flexibility and that he would need to see some U.S. reciprocity.Peskov spoke after one of Russia's most senior diplomats told the Interfax news agency earlier on Thursday that the Russian government had been in touch with members of Trump's political team during the U.S. election campaign and knew most of his entourage. (Editing by Mark Heinrich)"	[]	[]
